block.p: Germany's version of the C.I.A., the Foreign Intelligence Service, has prepared a secret report charging that Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, put more than $100 million in foreign bank accounts, some of it from drug trafficking.
The report, according to the newspaper Bild, called the Milosevic regime, ''an organized crime structure, engaged in drug trade, money laundering and other crimes.''

Germany's version of the C.I.A., the Foreign Intelligence Service, has prepared a secret report charging that Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, put more than $100 million in foreign bank accounts, some of it from drug trafficking.
The report, according to the newspaper Bild, called the Milosevic regime, ''an organized crime structure, engaged in drug trade, money laundering and other crimes.''
It said Mr. Milosevic controlled bank accounts in several countries and funneled $100 million into Switzerland alone.
